title: Have Google Search results have become less relevant recently? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, Google Search Results are not getting worse, in fact, in most instances the results delivered by Google when a word/phrase/question is queried are becoming more accurate.  Google's been cracking down on web spam in recent years with its regular Algorithm updates.    These updates have made it nearly impossible to rank web pages that are irrelevant, incomplete, low quality and/or don't deliver (the most) valuable information on the web about the phrase being searched, on the first page of Google search results.  You're not the first to suggest that these updates might be backfiring by rendering results less relevant, less accurate and thereby worse.  In an article published on Search Engine Land, for instance, Danny Sullivan questioned whether Penguin Made Google's Search Results Better Or Worse?  Nevertheless, overall Google Search Results are getting better and more capable of delivering results that are personalized and accurate.   The trouble you're experiencing finding answers to questions you ask within the first few pages of Google search results may be related to the subject of the questions for which you're searching.  For instance, you mentioned that you were experiencing difficulty finding answers on questions relating to web development.  The trouble you're having may have more to do with proliferation of new web development terms and complex questions involving these terms flooding the web, than it does with the quality of Google's search results.    Give Google a bit of time to learn how to correctly interpret new web dev lingo and the results you're looking for will most likely start appearing where you'd expect and like for them to appear - i.e. on the first page of Google search results.   The same could be said for the other topics you mentioned, politics and business.

I just want to say, my search results are getting close to being all-advertising…that is one example of many. I “get” that they need to make money, but….really…. I don’t know, I suppose if I wanted to look at ads all day it might be fine. You have to go about %70 down the page, below the fold, before you catch a glimpse of any organic search results. Before that, you get: Paid ads.Map business locations.All’s fair in love and war right? Well, it has been going on a year when I know Google was informed (via their submission link) that these are TOWING COMPANIES & MAP SPAM. Read the investigations. What “CHARITY” do you know that is ready INSTANTLY to come pick up your vehicle. Naturally my view is just one more subjective opinion. But I think Google Search has got worse to the point of uselessness for many purposes. When Google first appeared it was marvellous. If I was searching for information I had many relevant hits on the first page. These days I often give up after looking through the first half dozen pages. Problems include hijacking of everyday words for company and product names, IT-related uses overshadowing older uses of words, people trying to sell me stuff, people trying to force their ridiculous world view down everyone’s throats, … and Google seems to be getting less and less effective at filtering out this crap. Perhaps SEO Is the real villain. After all, it is at root a form of deception. Its purpose is to get a higher ranking than the page content (or the product it is selling) deserves on merit. Today I tried to find information about the way that the human eye is adjusted to focus accurately at infinity in the early years of life (and how it may fail to do so if a person does to much reading/computing/TV-watching, rather then getting outdoors and active). I got reams of information about cameras and about other aspects of human vision but after trying to refine my search for thirty minutes by excluding dodgy words I simply gave up. This is just one example of many.

the people that said no are delusional or google fanboys lol. i used to be able to google very specific things and almost always the top result was exactly what i needed. it’s all clickbait-esque now. i google “how to bleach a shirt” and results are all like “top 5 ways to use bleach.” google “headache after waking up” and it’s like “top 10 most common causes of headache.” if i wanted these useless regurgitated “ranked” lists i’d look on facebook. it used to be so specific, i’m very disappointed. it’s seriously gone downhill just in the last couple months, i can’t believe i’d ever say this but i’m contemplating trying other search engines. honestly so annoying

YES! I type in “Dewalt Drill Backlash” and use Verbatim. ADS FOR SAWS! And it even continues to show backlash crossed out. Ummm, Verbatim means Whatever they feel like trying to sell you. If I want to buy a Saw, guess what I’ll type? If I want information about a SAW guess what I’ll type? IF I SAY VERBATIM, WHAT DO YOU THINK I MEAN? Ignore everything but a brand-name… sure, that’s EXACTLY what I mean! Google has turned to garbage. Trash. Crap. Junk. Might as well ask the ten pounds of fire-paper that I get in my mailbox every week.

This won't be the answer to the original question equested. Instead, I'll simply offer that there are rigorous scientific approaches to testing the quality of a search engine' relevance. A couple of anecdotal experiences is way too limiting of an approach to assess quality.  I was asked to measure the quality of search results of three separate search engines on behalf of a major organization. We built an interface that enabled us to swap out the underlying search engine or add and subtract search features to measure the impact on quality.  We were also able to measure relevance across various search types (i.e. Navigational, Informational and Transactional) It's not hard to accomplish this task and someone with the proper motivation could easily offer an ongoing test-bed that monitors the relevance of the major search engines on an on-going basis.  One of the challenges the search engines have is the increasing amount of content being published on the web. Let's take an imaginary point in time when there were just 1,000,000 pages on the Internet. For any search query, an engine has to select the top 0.00001% for the ten results that appear on page 1. Now that there are over a billion pages in the index, the algorithm has to select 0.00000001% of that vastly larger index to make it on to page 1.  So, does more content on the web make it easier or harder to choose the 10 best? I would suggest it makes it harder. This is one of the main motivators Google has for limiting the size of their searchable index to just the absolute best content.

In my opinion, Google search definitely seems to be getting worse. Returned results are becoming less and less relevant to search queries, especially when using long-tail queries. With all that ad revenue coming in, I'm guessing Google’s main focus is its business users. Unfortunately, end user experience is suffering. Forbes published this article on the decline. Is Google's Search Quality Starting To Decline?

Look at my pic: i love Google since i’m on the web. But i have to say: Google is getting worse. Too much adv above the fold on serps and search results are not so accurate as before. I think they are too much focused on competing with Fb for the “king of the web” crown but doing it they are making their primary service, web search, worst every year. Look at this, it was 5 years ago: https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/jw_on_tech/2012/03/13/why-i-left-google/

I think it's the natural consequences of so many businesses and bloggers working so hard to "game the system" over the years. When there are still so many abandoned or garbage-y pages out there, and so many attempts to subvert search engines' results, it's not Google's fault.  UNFORTUNATELY, Google (and many other search engines) seem to have taken away many useful search operators (or hidden them very well) so as to make it harder to get a straight answer and get out.

On the contrary, it’s getting better. Google and other search engines from the start have been fighting with “growth hackers” who try to use their algorithms to push their content, instead of what a searcher might be looking for. Google’s RankBrain AI is now the third strongest signal used in Google search results, and it’s only likely to grow. It is in Google’s financial interest to provide the best search results, and keep their customers searching and happy.

My experience is that Google’s results are becoming laughably bad. I’m not exactly sure which of their algorithm updates is involved but I will often get multiple results that are completely unrelated to what I’m searching for. Here’s an example. I was searching for "what does jail status other mean". Two of three of the results on the first page were about PayPal.

It depends. If you are a smartphone only user your going to love it. It is speedy and shows up what most people search for instantly such as shopping and directions. They cater to (guess your search) which Google used to be known to be different until the Obama era. If you are outside of the phone crowd you will find an increasingly difficult time as you are going against what the AI thinks most people wants. Google uses Watson AI (the crappy one that lost at Jeopardy). The Watson AI won because it got feedback from other players which sadly Google does not. Google does not believe in feedback as most monolithic corporations. The end user is just a product. Google was not always this way.

Yes, Google sucks. All search engines suck now. The phrasing, shorthand and other techniques that used to work, just don’t anymore. Really, anything “free” sucks, because it means they’re using the users to generate revenue - instead of operating on a formal income stream. Yeah that sounds like dated thinking, but how else can there exist real incentive to actually provide what’s being paid for? Many of us would pay a premium to access a search engine that serves up what we’re actually searching - and nothing else. Someone with the resources to make this happen will eventually recognize and figure out how to meet this demand. When they do, there’s money waiting for them. I’d pay more monthly than what I pay for internet access, just to *ahem* access the internet.

Hello, Searched for this question, Tonight I was watching “ The lion king “ for the first time. Had to miss a portion of it when I got a call. Now I missed the plot. Suddenly I don't see Simba's father mufasa and his brother scar was named king. And Simba was with pumba and timoon. So during the commercial I googled to see the plot I missed. Which answers your question, I suppose.  Ciao!

Google search isn’t getting worse! Its just because of some SEO Companies that results are not matching with the expected results. Optimising wrong keywords, generic keywords, extra broad keywords result in such bad experience.
It absolutely has. Case in point: their shopping results. I can search for a plus size men's trench coat and get a whole page of results for women's clothing. Really, Google?

It would be easier to address this if you provided specific examples of what you are seeing. But you could try advanced search features, such as using the minus sign immediately before a term you want to eliminate, or putting a word in quotes to mandate its inclusion, or putting an exact phrase in quotes so that it must be included. You could also try the search on another search engine to see if it produces better results. For example, SweetSearch, A Search Engine for Students, only searches a whitelist of high quality websites, and offers a version for News and another for History websites.

no google is still a best search engine. There is no other search engine in comparison to google. Therefore most of the seo expert works on google.
